  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
The merger of Daimler and Chrysler was one of the
  most expensive – and least fruitful – in American automaking
  history. Now DaimlerChrysler is dropping its struggling Chrysler Group, which
  is getting picked up by a private equity firm. Anthony Mason will have the
  story of the sale and Nancy Cordes will look at what’s pinching
  American automakers, from union costs to pensions and sales numbers.
 
Turning to Iraq, we’ll have two
  stories. First: the anatomy of an ambush. Mark Strassmann will report on the
  abduction of three American soldiers in Saturday’s early morning hours
  south of Baghdad.
  He’ll break down what happened and the effort to get the missing
  soldiers back.
And it has been reported that between 100,000 and
  300,000 barrels of Iraq’s
  oil has been unaccounted for – that’s every day for the past four
  years. Our Sharyl Attkisson asks why – was it corruption, smuggling or
  simply poor accounting – and tells what the loss means for U.S.
  consumers.
Today cycling great Floyd Landis opened his doping
  hearing denying the charge. He also criticized the testing procedure used by
  the Tour de France, Bill Whitaker will report.
As for health news, I’ll talk with our Dr. Jon
  LaPook about the surprising study that shows the number of women older than
  40 getting mammograms is on the decline. It is the first time the rate has
  fallen, according to the National Cancer Institute.
 
And I’ll wrap-up our broadcast with the first
  piece in a series we’ve been working on called “Gotta Have It:
  The Hard Sell To Kids.” I’ll take a look at the multitude of ways
  cartoon characters and other faces our kids and grandkids love are used to
  market everything from junk food to exercise. Experts say there’s more
  at stake here than just money.
 
I hope you’ll join us.
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
